string.text: USEFUL INFORMATION
Fact #
Rank has eight different levels and can be increased through almost any in-game activity. Certain features may require reaching a high rank before they can be used or fully unlocked.
Achievements can be unlocked through in-game accomplishments or by reaching statistical milestones. Every achievement is unlocked with an appropriate reward.

Basic, advanced, and expert tools are required by most technicians in order to perform certain upgrades on weapons and outfits. Such items can often be found in stashes received as rewards for completing tasks.
Sleep deprivation is an optional feature where the passage of time and usage of consumables will eventually require you to rest. Failing to do so may have dire consequences.

Helicopter gunships can be seen patrolling many of the Zone's locations. When engaged in combat, members of the helicopter's faction may often call on it for air support to help destroy attacking or defending forces.

Ironman mode gives a true sense of mortality. When your character is killed all saves for that specific playthrough are deleted and can never be restored. Pick your faction and starting location wisely.

Gunsmith and sewing kits are used to repair your weapons and outfits respectively when out in the field. Each allows up to three uses and are best used to repair items of greater value than the kits themselves.

Backpacks can be bought or found and then used to create a custom stash. Stashes created by you are never de-spawned nor are they ever looted by other stalkers. They are permanent until all items are removed.
Sleeping bags are a great way to rest in the Zone if you are unable to find a decent bed to sleep in. They can be purchased from most major traders or potentially found in another stalker's stash.
Truck Cemetery is a large graveyard of irradiated agricultural, civilian, and military vehicles. As a great place to hide a stash, an eagle-eyed stalker may find many valuables within the wreckage.
Artefact types are indicative of the anomalies they are found in. Want one that boosts your burn resistance? Search for a 'Burner' or 'Comet' anomaly and go hunting with your detector.
Completing tasks for factions will increase your goodwill with them. As it increases, their traders will gradually offer you greater discounts and more valuable items.
Most tasks can be cancelled after you agree to complete them. You can do this by speaking with the stalker who gave you the task. Cancelling a task will decrease your reputation and goodwill.
Reputation is gained and lost by helping or harming non-hostile stalkers respectively.
Remember to ask regular stalkers if they have any jobs available. Just because they aren't anybody important doesn't mean they won't be willing to pay you to do their dirty work.
Rostok's arena hosts two types of competitions: traditional fights where stalkers battle each other for cash rewards, and challenges, where they attempt to kill increasingly harder mutants.
Online exclusion radius creates a no-spawn zone around you; preventing mutants and other stalkers spawning unfairly and dangerously close.
Freedom completely occupies Yanov station in Jupiter after a mysterious stalker assisted them several years ago. Some of their well-known members have since relocated to their new northern base.
The 'Completionist' achievement is received for unlocking all other available achievements.
It is much easier to avoid detection when travelling during the night or through heavy rain. However, you risk encountering fierce nocturnal mutants.
You won't be able to issue orders to companions if you leave them behind. Companions in Wait or Patrol modes will not travel with you when you move into a different level.
Vodka is a useful alternative to anti-radiation drugs if they are in short supply. It also weighs quite a lot and increases your hunger when used.
Not sure how to earn that achievement? Don't know what this feature does? The 'Guide' tab of your PDA has all essential articles unlocked right from the start when you create your character.

Due to differing chemical composition, tracers in Western-made ammunition will glow red, whereas those of Eastern origin will glow green. This may help indicate what kind of weapon your enemy is using.
Other stalkers may sometimes load their weapons with armour-piercing ammunition. These rounds will punch through weak materials and damage those hiding behind.
Buckshot will have little effect against body armour unless you aim for the head. However, it will completely decimate anyone wearing nothing but a simple jacket.
Tactics and terrain are just as important to winning a fight as your choice of weapon and ammunition. Spending the time to create an ambush could give you a massive advantage.
Traders restock their supplies every 48-hours. They will also refuse to buy any equipment from you if its condition falls below 75 percent.
Avoid standing next to red barrels in a fight as they will explode when shot. However, if a hostile stalker should wander next to one a few well placed bullets will send them flying.
Turning on your flashlight will alert any nearby enemies to your location. Shining it directly in their eyes at close range may make it harder for them to shoot you.
Can't find tools for a technician to upgrade your gear? Legend has it that an elderly man in the Red Forest doesn't require them, but charges a small fortune for his services.
Most stalkers go through what they call the "hobo phase", which describes a period of poor equipment and limited finances when first exploring the Zone.
You can right-click weapons to unload them of their ammunition and remove any scopes, suppressors, and grenade launchers which they might have attached.
Mutant parts can be sold to the Ecologists at their scientific laboratories. Ordinary stalkers won't have any interest in purchasing them from you.
Each faction has their own unique arsenal. Because of this, weapons and ammunitions considered uncommon in one region of the Zone will likely be very prominent in others.
Collect cheap weapons in good condition, pay a technician to repair them fully, and then sell them to a trader to make a small but easy profit.
Plant a butterfly mine near a hostile stalker's fallen ally - when he tries to loot he will blow himself up in the process.
Eating food won't heal you but will instead cure your hunger. Being hungry reduces your energy regeneration.
Grenades and most other explosive objects will fragment when detonated. The shrapnel produced can reach much farther than the initial explosion's kill radius.
You can kick physical objects such as crates and boxes, and even small mutants with a low body mass. Bind this ability to a key in the controls menu to use it.
Found a cool area and would like to revisit it later? You can double-click almost anywhere on the world map to mark locations.
Try to be aware of how much noise you are creating - mutants and other stalkers will hear you if you don't move about with caution in mind.
Not sure if the path ahead is safe? Throw a bolt in that direction to see if any anomalies react to it.
Use your binoculars to scout out the area surrounding you. Any nearby entities will be indicated by a rectangle.
Want to challenge your proficiency with weapons? Enable the enhanced recoil feature for more realistic multi-directional recoil.
Protective equipment doesn't make radiation a non-issue, but it does reduce its effects, allowing you to spend more time in contaminated areas.
Your relation to another stalker can often be identified by the usage of colour on the interface. Neutrals appear yellow, friendlies appear green, and enemies appear red.
Bodies can be dragged out of sight by looking towards them and pressing the key prompts on-screen.
Stalkers will heal themselves during battle if they have a medical kit in their inventory, but will require the assistance of another if they are mortally wounded.
Don't become too focused on a specific target, their allies will use this to their advantage by trying to flank you.
